<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports
required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or </I><I>15(d)</I><I> of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or for such shorter period that the
registrants were required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;have been subject to
such filing requirements for the past
90&nbsp;days.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Yes&nbsp;X&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;&#95;&#95;&#95;

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Indicate by
check mark whether the registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined by Rule
12b-2 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).</I>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD nowrap align="left"><B>Registrant</B><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><B>Yes</B><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><B>No</B><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
</TR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by The Southern Company,
Alabama Power Company, Georgia Power Company, Gulf Power Company, Mississippi
Power Company, Savannah Electric and Power Company and Southern Power Company.
Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by
such company on its own behalf. Each company makes no representation as to
information relating to the other companies.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q contains forward-looking statements in
addition to historical information. Forward-looking information includes,
among other things, statements concerning the strategic goals for Southern
Company&#146;s wholesale business, estimated construction and other expenditures. In
some cases, forward-looking statements can be identified by terminology such as
&#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148;
&#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;projects,&#148; &#147;predicts,&#148; &#147;potential&#148; or &#147;continue&#148; or
the negative of these terms or other comparable terminology. The registrants
caution that there are various important factors that could cause actual
results to differ materially from those indicated in the forward-looking
statements; accordingly, there can be no assurance that such indicated results
will be realized. These factors include:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the impact of recent and future federal and state regulatory change, including legislative and regulatory initiatives
regarding deregulation and restructuring of the electric utility industry and also changes in environmental, tax and other
laws and regulations to which Southern Company and its subsidiaries are subject, as well as changes in application of
existing laws and regulations;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>current and future litigation, regulatory investigations, proceedings or inquiries, including the pending EPA civil actions
against certain Southern Company subsidiaries and current IRS audits;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effects, extent and timing of the entry of additional competition in the markets in which Southern Company&#146;s
subsidiaries operate;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">

</TR>

</TABLE>

</TR>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY<BR>
AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">7
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left">
<A name="106"></A>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION<BR>
&nbsp;<br>
SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Southern Company&#146;s
primary business of electricity sales in the Southeast by the retail operating
companies &#150; Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and
Savannah Electric &#150; and Southern Power. Southern Power is an electric
wholesale generation subsidiary with market-based rate authority. Southern
Company&#146;s other business activities include investments in synthetic fuels and
leveraged lease projects, telecommunications, energy-related services and
natural gas marketing. For additional information on these businesses, see
BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Retail Operating Companies,&#148; &#147;Southern Power&#148;
and &#147;Other Business&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s second quarter and year-to-date 2004 earnings were
$352&nbsp;million ($0.48 per share) and $683&nbsp;million ($0.93 per share),
respectively, compared with $432&nbsp;million ($0.60 per share) and $730&nbsp;million
($1.01 per share) in the second quarter and year-to-date 2003. The decreases
in second quarter and year-to-date 2004 results are attributed to a one-time
after-tax gain of $88&nbsp;million included in the second quarter 2003 from
termination of capacity sales contracts with Dynegy. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Uncontracted Generating
Capacity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on these
contract terminations. Earnings in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004
when compared to the same periods in 2003, excluding the Dynegy contract
termination, increased due to a number of positive factors including growth in
customers, increased consumption of electricity by existing customers in the
Southern Company service area, and generally more favorable weather conditions,
as well as new generating capacity available for sale in wholesale markets.
This new capacity led to increases in wholesale revenues from new contracts and
sales of uncontracted capacity in those wholesale markets. These positive
factors were partially offset by higher operations and maintenance cost in the
second quarter as some maintenance projects not completed in 2003 and earlier
this year were undertaken in the second quarter of 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="85%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="52%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">






<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding fuel revenues, which generally do not affect net
income, retail base revenues increased by $109&nbsp;million, or 7.1%, in the second
quarter 2004, and increased by $181&nbsp;million, or 6.2%, year-to-date 2004 when
compared to the same periods in 2003. In the second quarter and year-to-date
2004, retail kilowatt-hour energy sales increased by 5.3% and 4.9%,
respectively, over the same periods a year ago, primarily due to customer and
demand growth and the still improving economy evidenced by increases in
residential, commercial and industrial second quarter kilowatt-hour energy
sales of 8.5%, 5.1% and 3.0%, respectively. Year-to-date residential,
commercial and industrial kilowatt-hour energy sales increased by 6.9%, 4.3%
and 3.9%, respectively, when compared to the same period in 2003. In the second
quarter and year-to-date 2004, temperatures were slightly above normal, while
mild weather in the same periods last year resulted in reduced demand by retail
customers. The number of retail customers increased by 1.8%, and average
consumption by residential customers increased by 5.2% for the year-to-date
2004 when compared to year-to-date 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale. </I>Sales for resale revenues increased $20.8&nbsp;million, or
6.4% and $37.0&nbsp;million, or 5.6% for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004,
respectively, when compared to the same periods in the prior year. The
increase in revenues reflected new wholesale contracts and increases in fuel
revenues. An additional 2,407 megawatts of generating capacity were added in
June and October&nbsp;2003 by Southern Power. A portion of this new capacity
contributed to the increase in sales for resale revenues for the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 as a result of increased energy revenues from PPAs with
neighboring utilities. These increases in sales for resale revenues more than
offset the reduction in revenues resulting from the termination of contracts
with subsidiaries of Dynegy in May&nbsp;2003. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Uncontracted Generating Capacity&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on these contract terminations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other electric revenues. </I>In the second quarter and year-to-date 2004,
other electric revenues decreased $133.9&nbsp;million, or 58.7% and $132.3&nbsp;million
or 41.4%, respectively, because of the $142&nbsp;million in contract termination
revenues from Dynegy recorded in May&nbsp;2003. See &#147;Earnings&#148; discussion above for
additional information on these contract terminations. Excluding these
contract termination revenues, other electric revenues increased $8.3&nbsp;million
or 9.6% and $9.8&nbsp;million or 5.5% for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004,
respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2003 primarily as a result
of increased cogeneration sales and transmission revenue.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. During the second quarter and year-to-date periods of 2004,
fuel expense was higher due to an increase in the average unit cost of fuel, as
well as increased generating capacity at Southern Power. Total fuel generation
remained flat for the second quarter and increased 2.3% for the year-to-date
2004, when compared to the same periods in the prior year. For the second
quarter and year-to-date periods in 2004, the average unit cost of fuel per
kilowatt-hour generated increased 13.2% and 12.9%, respectively, when compared to
the same periods in the prior year. Increases in fuel expense at the retail
operating companies are generally offset by fuel revenues and do not affect net
income. See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC and State PSC Matters &#150; Retail
Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information. Southern Power&#146;s PPAs
generally provide that the purchasers are responsible for substantially all of
the costs of fuel.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power. </I>The increases in purchased power for the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 when compared with the same periods last year were
primarily due to increased demand for energy by retail customers and to
purchase energy used to meet off-system sales commitments. Also, at times
additional power was available for purchase from external parties at prices
lower than Southern Company&#146;s own system generation costs. These expenses do
not have a significant impact on earnings since energy expenses are generally
offset by energy revenues.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">14
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations and maintenance expenses. </I>The increases in other
operations and maintenance expenses in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004
are mainly attributable to increases in administrative and general,
transmission and distribution maintenance and other production expenses.
Administrative and general expenses increased $14.7&nbsp;million, or 6.5% and $40.5
million, or 9.5%, for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004, respectively,
primarily as a result of payroll and employee benefits costs. Transmission and
distribution expenses increased $18.6&nbsp;million or 13.7% and $30.3&nbsp;million or
11.9% for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004, respectively, as a result
of completing work delayed from 2003. Other production expenses were up $7.1
million or 2.2% and $14.5&nbsp;million, or 2.3% for the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004, respectively, due to increased expenses primarily resulting from
the operation of Southern Power&#146;s new generating facilities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases of $24.8&nbsp;million and $29.2&nbsp;million, respectively, in depreciation and
amortization expense when compared to the same periods in 2003 are primarily
the result of increased amortization of regulatory liabilities at Georgia Power
and Mississippi Power. The decreases in Georgia Power&#146;s depreciation and
amortization expenses ($17&nbsp;million and $35&nbsp;million for the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004, respectively) were caused primarily by lower regulatory
charges needed to levelize purchased power capacity costs under the terms of
the retail rate order effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. See Note 1 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Depreciation and Amortization&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information. The decreases in Mississippi
Power&#146;s second quarter and year-to-date 2004 depreciation and amortization
expenses ($8&nbsp;million and $7&nbsp;million for the second quarter and year-to-date
2004, respectively) are primarily the result of the amortization of a
regulatory liability as approved by the Mississippi PSC. The Mississippi PSC
issued an interim accounting order in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi Power
to expense and record in 2003 a regulatory liability in the amount of
approximately $60&nbsp;million. Based on the final Mississippi PSC order issued May
25, 2004 that approved this treatment, Mississippi Power recorded a credit to
amortization of the regulatory liability of $8.3&nbsp;million during the second
quarter of 2004. The year-to-date decreases are partially offset by increases
in depreciable plant in service, primarily as a result of Southern Power&#146;s
Stanton Unit A, which was placed in service in October&nbsp;2003. Reference is made
to Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mississippi
Power Regulatory Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements and &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters&#148; herein for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
increases in taxes other than income taxes over the comparable periods last
year are primarily a result of increases in payroll taxes, property taxes on
new facilities and higher tax assessments on property. Also, franchise and
gross receipts taxes increased for the respective periods due to the increase
in revenues from energy sales.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest income. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004 decreases in
interest income when compared to the same periods in the prior year resulted
from $15.6&nbsp;million of interest received from a federal income tax settlement in
the second quarter of 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in other income (expense), net reflect decreased rental income at
Georgia Power of $4.0&nbsp;million and $2.5&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as the
impact of the ESOP contribution in June&nbsp;2004 of $6.2&nbsp;million when compared to
the same periods in 2003. The year-to-date 2004 decrease in other income
(expense), net also reflects a $5.0&nbsp;million decrease related to the 2003
favorable resolution of a loss contingency by Georgia Power.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">15
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors. These factors include the retail operating companies&#146; ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while
containing costs and to recover costs related to growing demand and
increasingly stricter environmental standards. Another major factor is the
profitability of the competitive market-based wholesale generating business and
federal regulatory policy, which may impact Southern Company&#146;s level of
participation in this market. Future earnings for the electricity business in
the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is
subject to a number of factors, including weather, competition, new energy
contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand and the
rate of economic growth in the service area. For additional information
relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148;
in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151;
&#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>New Source Review Actions and Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information, including information on certain environmental
litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;  RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151;
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Company in Item
7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;New Source
Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were
increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the
extent alleged violations under either the New Source Review litigation or
Plant Wansley environmental litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The cases against Alabama Power,
Georgia Power and Savannah Electric have been effectively stayed pending final
resolution of the TVA case. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review,
the Court of Appeals&#146; decision became final. Alabama Power and the EPA jointly
notified the District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, where the
case against Alabama Power is pending and requested that the stay be lifted.
On June&nbsp;16, 2004, the District Court lifted the stay, placing the case back
onto the District Court&#146;s active docket. At this time, no party to the case
against Georgia Power and Savannah Electric has sought to reopen that case,
which remains administratively closed in the District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia. On June&nbsp;10, 2004, the U.S. District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia granted Georgia Power&#146;s motion in the Plant Wansley
environmental litigation for partial summary judgment regarding emissions
offsets. The case has been removed from the court&#146;s trial calendar due to
pending motions for summary judgment, and a new trial date has not been
scheduled. An adverse outcome in any one of these cases could require
substantial capital expenditures that cannot be determined at this time and
could possibly require payment of substantial penalties. This could affect
future results of operations, cash flows, and possibly financial condition if
such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">16
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Global Warming Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A nearly
identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same court.
The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups also
seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs seek a
judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable for
creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits;
however, it intends to vigorously defend against these claims. While the
outcome cannot be determined at this time, an adverse judgment could result in
substantial capital expenditures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Other Environmental Matters</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the EPA redesignated the Birmingham, Alabama area from
nonattainment to attainment under the one-hour ozone national ambient air
quality standard. On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone
nonattainment designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new
eight-hour standard. Areas within the Southern Company&#146;s service area that
have been designated as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard
include Birmingham, Macon (Georgia), and a 20-county area within metropolitan
Atlanta. Under the implementation provisions of the new rule, the EPA
announced that the one-hour ozone standard will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005.
Areas classified as &#147;severe&#148; nonattainment areas under the one-hour standard
will not be required to impose emissions fees as a result of nonattainment.
Georgia Power, therefore, will no longer be subject to imposition of emissions
fees if the Atlanta area does not come into attainment with the one-hour
standard. The impact of the eight-hour designations and the new standards will
depend on the development and implementation of applicable state regulations
and therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, the EPA issued its recommendations for areas to be
designated &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the fine particle national ambient air quality
standard. Areas within Southern Company&#146;s service area that were included in
the EPA&#146;s proposed fine particulate matter designations include 24 counties in
the metro-Atlanta area; counties surrounding Macon, Athens, and Columbus, Georgia;
counties surrounding Birmingham, Alabama; and counties in Alabama and Georgia
near Chattanooga, Tennessee. Alabama Power, Georgia
Power and Southern Power own several plants located within the counties
proposed for the nonattainment designations. The EPA plans to make final
nonattainment designations for fine particulate matter by the end of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to Georgia. These rules specify that the State of
Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by April&nbsp;2005, and
affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by May&nbsp;1, 2007.
The impact of these regulations will depend on the development and approval of
Georgia&#146;s state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">17
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the
development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the
states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and State PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate Authority</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern
Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC
issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis
for measuring generation market power. This new interim approach includes a
pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share analysis, the results of
which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding generation market power. The
FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for rebutting these presumptions and
addresses mitigation measures for those entities that are found to have market
power. In the absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes
several cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by default. The FERC
also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt
a final methodology for assessing generation market power. Southern Company,
the retail operating companies and Southern Power believe that it may be
difficult for a traditional utility company, or an affiliate thereof, with a
significant load service obligation and generation to satisfy that obligation,
and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved RTO, to pass all aspects of
the market power screens as currently designed. However, each of the companies
believes that it has an appropriate basis to rebut the generation market power
presumption.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Transmission</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Plant McIntosh Construction Project</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs between Southern
Power and Georgia Power and Savannah Electric for Plant McIntosh capacity. In
April&nbsp;2003, Southern Power applied for FERC approval of these PPAs. In July
2003, the FERC accepted the PPAs to become effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, subject to
refund and ordered that hearings be held. To ensure the timely completion of
construction on McIntosh units 10 and 11 and their availability in the summer
of 2005 as supply side resources for the retail customers in the State of
Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric and Georgia Power requested the
Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the McIntosh construction project.
Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place the units in rate base at
a cost



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">18
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the unit operation and maintenance
costs as retail service expenses as may be approved by the Georgia PSC. The
Georgia PSC issued such an order on May&nbsp;18, 2004 and the transfer occurred on
May&nbsp;24, 2004. On May&nbsp;20, 2004,
Southern Power filed a request to withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the
ongoing FERC proceedings. On August 4, 2004, the FERC issued a notice
that it allowed the request to withdraw the PPAs to be accepted and
to become effective by operation of law on July 20, 2004. However,
the FERC made no determination on what additional steps may need to
be taken with respect to testimony provided in the proceedings. The ultimate
outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The May&nbsp;18, 2004 Georgia PSC order also directed Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric to file an application within 10&nbsp;days of completing such
purchase to amend the resource certificate granted by the Georgia PSC in 2002
to describe the capacity resource as being the McIntosh units 10 and 11 (as
opposed to the McIntosh PPAs), the approximate construction schedule (which is
not expected to change) and the proposed rate base treatment. The application
was filed on June&nbsp;3, 2004 and the Georgia PSC will have 180&nbsp;days to respond.
The Georgia PSC is expected to review the application in accordance with its
affiliate transaction guidelines, which require a lower of cost or market
approach unless otherwise determined by the Georgia PSC. Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric have submitted information showing that the book cost of the
McIntosh construction project is lower than its market value. However, full
recovery of the project costs depends on the outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s
review. In the event the Georgia PSC does not allow full recovery of the
project costs, then part of such costs may have to be written off in accordance
with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;90, &#147;Accounting for Abandonments and Disallowed Plant
Costs.&#148; At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the investment in the McIntosh construction project
totaled approximately $355.2&nbsp;million and $69.7&nbsp;million for Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric, respectively. The ultimate outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s
review cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Georgia Power Retail Rate Case</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;1, 2004, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC for an
approximate 7&nbsp;percent increase in retail revenues, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005.
The requested increase is based on a future test year ending July&nbsp;31, 2005 and
a proposed retail return on common equity of 12.5&nbsp;percent. Georgia Power is
currently operating under a three-year retail rate order that expires December
31, 2004. Under the terms of the existing order, earnings are evaluated
annually against a retail return on common equity range of 10&nbsp;percent to 12.95
percent. Two-thirds of any earnings above the 12.95&nbsp;percent return are applied
to rate refunds, with the remaining one-third retained by Georgia Power. The
order required Georgia Power to file a general rate case on July&nbsp;1, 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in retail revenues is being requested to cover the higher
costs of purchased power; operating and maintenance expenses; environmental
compliance; and continued investment in new generation, transmission and
distribution facilities to support growth and ensure reliability. Georgia Power
expects the Georgia PSC to issue a final order in this matter during December
2004. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; Other Matters&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Georgia Power Retail Rate
Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Alabama Power Environmental Rate Filing</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;2, 2004, Alabama Power made a filing with the Alabama PSC to
establish a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of retail costs associated
with environmental laws, regulations or other such mandates. If approved, the
rate mechanism would begin operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provide for the
recovery of these costs pursuant to a factor that will be calculated annually.
It is anticipated that for the first two years of the increase, retail rates
would increase under the proposed mechanism by approximately 1% ($33&nbsp;million)
in 2005 and approximately an additional 1% ($30&nbsp;million) in 2006. Such
environmental cost recovery would include operations and maintenance expense,
depreciation and a return on invested capital. The outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Mississippi Power Retail Rate Filing</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On December&nbsp;5, 2003, Mississippi Power filed a request with the Mississippi PSC
to include 266 megawatts of Plant Daniel Units 3 and 4 generating capacity not
included in jurisdictional cost of service. As part of Mississippi Power&#146;s
proposal to include the additional Plant Daniel capacity in retail rates, the
Mississippi PSC, at the time of such filing, issued an interim accounting order
in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi Power to expense and record in 2003 a
regulatory liability in the amount of approximately $60&nbsp;million while the
Mississippi PSC fully considered the entire request. On May&nbsp;25, 2004, the
Mississippi PSC issued an order related to this matter. The Mississippi PSC
approved Mississippi Power&#146;s request to reclassify the 266 megawatts of Plant
Daniel Unit 3 and 4 capacity to jurisdictional cost of service effective
January&nbsp;1, 2004 and authorized Mississippi Power to include the related costs
and revenue credits in jurisdictional rate base, cost of service and revenue
requirement calculations for purposes of retail rate recovery. Mississippi
Power will amortize the regulatory liability established pursuant to the
Mississippi PSC&#146;s interim order in December&nbsp;2003 as an increase to earnings as
follows: $16.5&nbsp;million in 2004, $25.1&nbsp;million in 2005, $13.0&nbsp;million in 2006
and $5.7&nbsp;million in 2007.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Mississippi PSC also approved Mississippi Power&#146;s
requested changes to PEP, including the use of a forward-looking test year,
with appropriate oversight; annual, rather than semi-annual, filings; and
certain changes to the performance indicator mechanisms. Rate changes will be
limited to 4% of retail revenues annually under the revised PEP. The
Mississippi PSC will review all aspects of PEP in 2007. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mississippi Power Regulatory
Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The retail operating companies each have established fuel cost recovery rates
approved by their respective state PSCs. In recent months, the companies have
experienced higher than expected fuel costs for coal and gas. Those higher
fuel costs have increased the under recovered fuel costs included in the
Condensed Balance Sheets herein. The companies will continue to monitor the
under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these higher fuel costs.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Mirant Related Matters</I>

Southern Company has various contingent liabilities associated with Mirant,
including guarantees of contractual commitments, litigation and joint and
several liabilities in connection with the consolidated federal income tax
return. The ultimate outcome of such contingent liabilities cannot now be
determined.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future

the measures ordered by the NRC to be in effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been
finalized based on current interpretations of the requirements. Alabama Power
and Georgia Power &#151; based on its ownership interest &#151; currently estimate their
respective expenditures related to these security measures to total $9.6
million and $9.3&nbsp;million, of which $9.3&nbsp;million and $1.3&nbsp;million will be
capitalized. These estimates are subject to change in the event additional NRC
guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Southern Company&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Southern Company and its
subsidiaries cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not
anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings
would have a material adverse effect on Southern Company&#146;s financial
statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Southern Company&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;ACCOUNTING POLICIES&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;&#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for a complete discussion of Southern Company&#146;s critical accounting
policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent
Obligations, and Plant Daniel Capacity. Also see Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information related to Mississippi
Power&#146;s request to include the Plant Daniel capacity in jurisdictional cost of
service and the related Mississippi PSC order.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Southern Company prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no
impact on Southern Company&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption,
Southern Company and the retail operating companies deconsolidated certain
wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred securities since Southern
Company and the retail operating companies do not meet the definition of
primary beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. In addition,
Southern Company consolidated its 85% limited partnership investment in an
energy/telecom venture capital fund that was previously accounted for under the
equity method. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
additional information related to the adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Southern Company has elected to apply this treatment
prospectively. Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the
subsidy effected in the Medicare Act, Southern Company does not anticipate a
material impact on its financial statements from the adoption of FSP No.&nbsp;106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Southern Company&#146;s financial condition during the first six
months of 2004 included $1.0&nbsp;billion used for gross property additions to
utility plant. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements
were primarily obtained from net proceeds from short- and long-term security
issuances of approximately $685&nbsp;million and operating activities. See Southern
Company&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows and &#147;Financing
Activities&#148; herein for further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;&#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Company in Item
7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Southern Company&#146;s capital requirements
for its construction program and other funding requirements associated with
scheduled maturities of long-term debt, as well as the related interest,
preferred stock dividends, leases, trust funding requirements and other
purchase commitments. Approximately $924&nbsp;million will be required by June&nbsp;30,
2005 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company intends to meet its future capital needs through internal cash
flow and external security issuances. The amounts and timing of additional
equity capital to be raised will be contingent on Southern Company&#146;s investment
opportunities. The retail operating companies and Southern Power plan to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past, which were primarily from operating cash
flows, security issuances and term loan and short-term borrowings. However,
the amount, type and timing of any financings, if needed, will depend upon
market conditions and regulatory approval. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148;
in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">22
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern
Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets because of
the continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, as
well as scheduled maturities of long-term debt. To meet short term cash needs
and contingencies, the Southern Company system had at June&nbsp;30, 2004
approximately $191&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and approximately $3.5
billion of unused credit arrangements with banks, of which $251&nbsp;million expire
in 2004, $1.5&nbsp;billion expire in 2005 and $1.7&nbsp;billion expire in 2006 and
beyond. Of the facilities maturing in 2004 and 2005, $1.22&nbsp;billion contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date and
$215&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing one-year term loans executable at the
expiration date. These unused credit arrangements also provide liquidity
support to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper programs.
Southern Company expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The retail operating companies may also meet short-term cash needs
through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of
each of the retail operating companies. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the Southern Company
system had outstanding commercial paper of $727&nbsp;million and extendible
commercial notes of $10.9&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately
met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit without
maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;&#147;Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 7 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Operating Leases&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s lease
of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company and its subsidiaries do not have any credit agreements that
would require material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result
of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts that could require
collateral &#151; but not accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical
electricity purchases and sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases and
agreements covering interest rate swaps. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the maximum
potential collateral requirements were approximately $429.8&nbsp;million.
Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company guaranty,
letter of credit or cash.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Southern Company is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, the retail operating companies have
limited exposure to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices
and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in
electricity prices, the retail operating companies and Southern Power enter
into fixed price contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the
wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas
purchases. Also, the retail operating companies have each implemented
fuel-hedging


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">23
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Southern Company in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In the first six months of 2004, Southern Company subsidiaries issued $775
million of senior notes, $265&nbsp;million of other long-term debt, $175&nbsp;million of
preferred stock and $62&nbsp;million of common stock through employee and director
stock plans. The issuances were primarily used to refund senior notes and
other long-term debt and to fund ongoing construction projects. The remainder
was used to repay short-term debt. See Southern Company&#146;s Condensed
Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details on financing
activities during the first six months of 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;S 4.00%
Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2011 and $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;T 5.75% Senior
Public Income Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these sales were
used in March&nbsp;2004 to redeem all of its outstanding Series&nbsp;H 6.70% Senior
Insured Quarterly Notes due March&nbsp;1, 2011 and Series&nbsp;D 6 5/8% Senior Notes due
March&nbsp;31, 2039.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further in January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power Capital Trust VII, a statutory
trust, sold $200&nbsp;million of its 5 7/8% Trust Preferred Securities, which are
guaranteed by Georgia Power. The net proceeds from this issuance were used to
redeem 6.85% Trust Preferred Securities of Georgia Power Capital Trust IV. In
connection with this transaction, Georgia Power issued $206&nbsp;million of its junior subordinated
debentures to Georgia Power Capital Trust VII.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">24
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 4,000,000 shares ($100&nbsp;million
aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Cumulative, Par
Value $1 Per Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) and $200&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Z
5.125% Senior Notes due February&nbsp;15, 2019. The proceeds from these sales were
used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding short-term indebtedness
and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous
construction program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in February&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;U
Floating Rate Senior Notes due February&nbsp;17, 2009. The proceeds of this sale
were used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued $40&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;F Floating
Rate Senior Notes due March&nbsp;9, 2009. The proceeds from this sale, along with
other monies of Mississippi Power were used to repay $80
million aggregate principal amount of Mississippi Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;D Floating
Rate Senior Notes due March&nbsp;12, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, in April&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series
AA 5 5/8% Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2034 and terminated $150&nbsp;million of swaps
at a gain of $6&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used together with
other funds to redeem, in May&nbsp;2004, $200&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount
of the Series&nbsp;J 6.75% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;30, 2039. The gain from the
terminated swaps was deferred in Other Comprehensive Income and will be
amortized to income over the life of the Series&nbsp;AA Senior Notes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in April&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $35&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;J 5.875%
Senior Notes due April&nbsp;1, 2044. The proceeds from this issue were used for
general corporate purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction
program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, in April&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued 1,200,000 Depositary Shares
($30&nbsp;million aggregate stated capital) each representing one-fourth of a share
of 5.25% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock, cumulative, par value $100 per share. The
proceeds from this sale were primarily used to redeem various issues of
preferred stock and the remainder was used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further, in June, 2004, Savannah Electric issued 1,800,000 shares ($45
million aggregate par value) of 6.00% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock, non-cumulative,
par value $25 per share. The proceeds from this sale were used to repay a
portion of its outstanding short-term indebtedness that had been incurred
primarily to finance the purchase of its share of Units 10 and 11 of Plant
McIntosh.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2004, Alabama Power has entered into interest rate
hedging transactions related to the anticipated issuance of senior notes
totaling approximately $125&nbsp;million. The notes are expected to be issued in
2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries plan to continue, to the extent
possible, a program to retire higher-cost debt and replace these securities
with lower-cost capital.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The market price of Southern Company&#146;s common stock at June&nbsp;30, 2004 was
$29.15 per share and the book value was $13.43 per share, representing a
market-to-book ratio of 217%, compared to $30.25, $13.13 and 230%,
respectively, at the end of 2003. The dividend for the second quarter 2004 was
$0.35 per share compared to $0.3425 per share in the second quarter 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">25
</DIV>

    <TD nowrap><B>Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Controls and Procedures.</B>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Evaluation of disclosure controls and procedures.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">As of the end of the period covered by this quarterly report, Southern Company,
the retail operating companies and Southern Power conducted separate
evaluations under the supervision and with the participation of each company&#146;s
management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial
Officer, of the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures (as
defined in Sections&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934). Based upon those evaluations, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief
Financial Officer, in each case, concluded that the disclosure controls and
procedures are effective in alerting them in a timely manner to material
information relating to each company (including its consolidated subsidiaries)
required to be included in periodic filings with the SEC.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in internal controls.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">There have been no changes in Southern Company&#146;s, the retail operating
companies&#146; or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial reporting (as
such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934) during the second quarter of 2004 that have materially
affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect, Southern Company&#146;s, the
retail operating companies&#146; or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial
reporting.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">26
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="left">
<A name="111"></A>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the second
quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $104.3&nbsp;million and $195.0&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $106.6&nbsp;million and $198.4&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods of 2003. Earnings in the second quarter of 2004
decreased by $2.3&nbsp;million, or 2.2%, primarily due to higher maintenance
expenses and income and other taxes, partially offset by an increase in retail
base-rate revenues and a decrease in interest expense. Earnings year-to-date
2004 decreased by $3.4&nbsp;million, or 1.7%, principally due to higher maintenance
expense, depreciation expense, and income and other taxes. These increases
were partially offset by an increase in base rate revenues and a decrease in
interest expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">30.6</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales</I>. Excluding energy cost recovery revenues and revenues
associated with PPAs certificated by the Alabama PSC, which generally do not
affect net income, retail sales revenues increased by $25.5&nbsp;million, or 4.6%,
for the second quarter 2004 and $47.1&nbsp;million, or 4.5%, year-to-date 2004 when
compared to the corresponding periods in 2003. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information. Kilowatt-hour energy sales to
residential, commercial, and industrial customers increased 7.1%, 4.2%, and
3.0%, respectively, for the second quarter 2004 and increased 5.7%, 3.4% and
5.8%, respectively, year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding
periods of 2003 primarily due to more favorable weather conditions and improved
industrial sales mainly in the coal mining, primary metal and automotive
sectors.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">32
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues. </I>The increases in other revenues for the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 are attributed to a $3.4&nbsp;million increase in revenues
from cogeneration steam facilities due to increased fuel revenue resulting from
higher gas prices, a $1.6&nbsp;million increase in rent from pole attachments and a
$1.0&nbsp;million increase in transmission revenues when compared to the same
periods in 2003. Since cogeneration steam fuel revenues are generally offset
by fuel expense, these revenues do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense was higher in the second quarter 2004 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2003 mainly due to a 35.7% increase in
natural gas prices and a 10.8% increase in generation from natural gas-fired
generating facilities. The year-to-date 2004 increase in fuel expense when
compared to the same period in 2003 is mainly due to a 30.6% increase in
natural gas prices and a 24.0% increase in generation from gas-fired generating
facilities. These increases in generation from gas-fired facilities in the
second quarter and year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding periods
in 2003 are mainly due to an increased energy demand coupled with a 68.4%
decrease and a 48.4% decrease, respectively, in generation from Alabama Power&#146;s
hydroelectric facilities. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy
revenues, these expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings. See
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC and Alabama PSC Matters &#150; Retail Fuel Cost
Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates</I>. In the second quarter and year-to-date
2004, purchased power from non-affiliates increased when compared to the same
periods in 2003 primarily due to a 99.5% increase in energy purchased during
the second quarter 2004 even though purchased power prices decreased by 31.0%
during the second quarter 2004. Increased purchases were used to help meet the
increased energy demand for retail sales. These transactions did not have a
significant impact on earnings since energy purchases are generally offset by
energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Purchased power from affiliates increased
in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 over the same periods in 2003 due
to a PPA between Alabama Power and Southern Power that began in June&nbsp;2003. The
capacity component of these transactions was $13.0&nbsp;million in the second
quarter 2004 and $22.4&nbsp;million year-to-date 2004. Purchases of energy will
vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources
at each company. These transactions did not have a significant impact on
earnings since energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through
Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information on base rate adjustments for
certificated PPA expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increase in maintenance expense for the second
quarter 2004 when compared to the same period in 2003 is attributed to a $3.3
million increase in distribution expense, a $2.1&nbsp;million increase in Washington
County combined cycle turbine expense primarily due to caustic water damage and
a $1.9&nbsp;million increase in transmission expense. The year-to-date 2004
increase in maintenance expense is mainly due to a $6.6&nbsp;million increase in
distribution expense and a $3.7&nbsp;million increase in transmission expense.
These increases in transmission and distribution are mainly related to
scheduled work performed on overhead lines.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>The increases in depreciation and
amortization expense for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 are
attributed to an increase in utility plant in service when compared to the same
periods in 2003. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under
&#147;Construction Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes</I>. The second quarter 2004 increase in taxes
other than income taxes is mainly due to a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in property
tax expense as a result of a higher assessed property values when compared to
the corresponding period in 2003. The year-to-date 2004 increase in taxes
other than income

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">taxes when compared to the same period in 2003 is primarily due to a $2.7
million increase in payroll taxes, a $2.7&nbsp;million increase in property tax
expense and a $1.7&nbsp;million increase in the state public utility license tax
because of increased retail revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>. The decrease in interest
expense, net of amounts capitalized, during the second quarter and year-to-date
2004 when compared to the same periods in 2003 is the result of refinancing
higher cost debt. For additional information, see FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes</I>. Income tax expense increased for the second quarter and
year-to-date of 2004 due primarily to greater taxable income in the second
quarter of 2004 compared to 2003, resulting in an additional $6.5&nbsp;million tax
expense. Income tax expense increased an additional $4.2&nbsp;million in the second
quarter of 2004 due to a state income tax actualization adjustment. Also, an
income tax settlement which was recorded in 2003 resulted in a $4.7&nbsp;million
increase to net income in the second quarter of 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock</I>. Dividends on preferred stock increased for
the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 due to the issuance of 4,000,000
shares ($100&nbsp;million aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred
Stock, Cumulative, Par Value $1 Per Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) in
February&nbsp;2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Alabama Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors. These
factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring
utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in
Alabama Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>New Source Review
Actions</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information about these issues, including the EPA litigation, see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#150; Environmental Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air
Act were increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per
violation. To the extent alleged violations under the New Source Review
litigation are deemed to be continuing, this increased civil penalty amount
could apply to such violations found to continue after that date.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The case
against Alabama Power had been effectively stayed pending final resolution of
the TVA case. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review, the Court of
Appeals&#146; decision became final. Alabama Power and the EPA


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">34
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
