<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">jointly notified the District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, where
the case against Alabama Power is pending and requested that the stay be
lifted. On June&nbsp;16, 2004, the District Court lifted the stay, placing the case
back onto the District Court&#146;s active docket. An adverse outcome in this case
could require substantial capital expenditures that cannot be determined at
this time and could possibly require payment of substantial penalties. This
could affect future results of operations, cash flows, and possibly financial
condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Global Warming
Litigation</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A nearly
identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same court.
The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits;
however, it intends to vigorously defend against these claims. While the
outcome cannot be determined at this time, an adverse judgment could result in
substantial capital expenditures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Other Environmental
Matters</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the EPA redesignated the Birmingham, Alabama area from
nonattainment to attainment under the one-hour ozone national ambient air
quality standard. On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone
nonattainment designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new
eight-hour standard. Within Alabama Power&#146;s service area, Birmingham has been
designated as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard. Under the
implementation provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour
ozone standard will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. The impact of the eight-hour
designations and the new standards will depend on the development and
implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the
development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the
states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, the EPA issued its recommendations for areas to be
designated &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the fine particle national ambient air quality
standard. Areas within the Alabama Power&#146;s service area that were included in
the EPA&#146;s proposed fine particulate matter designations include counties
surrounding Birmingham, Alabama.
Alabama Power owns several plants located within the counties proposed for the
nonattainment designation. The EPA plans to make final nonattainment
designations for fine particulate matter by the end of 2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">35
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Alabama PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate
Authority</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Alabama
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14,
2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new
interim analysis for measuring generation market power. This new interim
approach includes a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share
analysis, the results of which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding
generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for
rebutting these presumptions and addresses mitigation measures for those
entities that are found to have market power. In the absence of specific
mitigation measures, the order includes several cost-based mitigation measures
that would apply by default. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking
proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for
assessing generation market power. Southern Company, the retail operating
companies, including Alabama Power, and Southern Power believe that it may be
difficult for a traditional utility company, or an affiliate thereof, with a
significant load service obligation and generation to satisfy that obligation,
and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved RTO, to pass all aspects of
the market power screens as currently designed. However, each of the companies
believes that it has an appropriate basis to rebut the generation market power
presumption.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Environmental Rate
Filing</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;2, 2004, Alabama Power made a filing with the Alabama PSC to
establish a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of retail costs associated
with environmental laws, regulations or other such mandates. If approved, the
rate mechanism would begin operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provide for the
recovery of these costs pursuant to a factor that will be calculated annually.
It is anticipated that for the first two years of the increase, retail rates
would increase under the proposed mechanism by approximately 1% ($33&nbsp;million)
in 2005 and approximately an additional 1% ($30&nbsp;million) in 2006. Such
environmental cost recovery would include
operations and maintenance expense, depreciation and a return on invested
capital. The outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">36
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2002, the Alabama PSC issued a consent order establishing the current
customer fuel rates, which Alabama Power began collecting in April&nbsp;2002. In
recent months, Alabama Power has experienced higher than expected fuel costs
for coal and gas. Those higher fuel costs have increased the under recovered
fuel costs included in the Condensed Balance Sheets herein. Alabama Power will
continue to monitor the under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these
higher fuel costs. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for information on nuclear security measures. Implementation plans for the
measures ordered by the NRC to be in effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been
finalized based on current interpretations of the requirements. Alabama Power
currently estimates its expenditures related to these security measures to
total $9.6&nbsp;million, of which $9.3&nbsp;million will be capitalized. These estimates
are subject to change in the event additional NRC guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Alabama Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Alabama Power cannot be predicted
at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if
any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Alabama Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Alabama Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Alabama Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on
Alabama Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Alabama
Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Alabama Power does not meet the definition of primary
beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the
adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Alabama Power has elected to apply this treatment prospectively.
Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the subsidy effected
in the Medicare Act, Alabama Power does not anticipate a material impact on its
financial statements from the adoption of FSP No.&nbsp;106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Alabama Power&#146;s financial condition during the first six
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $376&nbsp;million to utility
plant. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities and net proceeds from security
issuances of $269&nbsp;million. See Alabama Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash
Flows herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151;  &#147;Capital Requirements and
Contractual Obligations&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Alabama Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction
program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements. Approximately $525&nbsp;million will be required by June&nbsp;30, 2005 for
maturities of long-term debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described below,
Alabama Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past. The amount, type and
timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other
factors. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets primarily
because of scheduled maturities of long-term debt. To meet short-term cash
needs and contingencies, at June&nbsp;30, 2004 Alabama Power had $28&nbsp;million of cash
and cash equivalents, unused committed lines of credit of approximately $808
million (including $504
million of such lines which are dedicated to funding purchase obligations
relating to variable rate pollution control bonds) and an extendible commercial
note program. These lines of credit will expire at various times during 2004
($165&nbsp;million), 2005 ($418&nbsp;million) and 2007 ($225&nbsp;million). Alabama Power

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration.
Alabama Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company
subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible
commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Alabama Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. Alabama Power has regulatory authority for up
to $1&nbsp;billion of short-term borrowings. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, Alabama Power had
$46&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need
for working capital can be adequately met by issuing commercial paper or
utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are contracts that could require collateral &#150; but not
accelerated payment &#150; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales, fixed price physical gas purchases and agreements covering
interest rate swaps. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the maximum potential collateral
requirements were approximately $27&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be
provided for by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit or cash.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Alabama Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Alabama Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Alabama Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity
through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar
contracts for gas purchases. Alabama Power has also implemented a retail fuel
hedging program at the instruction of the Alabama PSC. The fair value of
derivative energy contracts at June&nbsp;30, 2004 was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Alabama Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In February&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 4,000,000 shares ($100&nbsp;million aggregate
stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Cumulative, Par Value $1 Per
Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) and $200&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Z 5.125% Senior
Notes due February&nbsp;15, 2019. The proceeds from these sales were used to repay
a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding short-term indebtedness and for other
general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous construction
program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;AA 5 5/8%
Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2034 and terminated $150&nbsp;million of swaps at a gain
of $6&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used together with other funds
to redeem, in May&nbsp;2004, $200&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of the
Series&nbsp;J 6.75% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;30, 2039. The gain from the terminated
swaps was deferred in Other Comprehensive Income and will be amortized to
income over the life of the Series&nbsp;AA Senior Notes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2004, Alabama Power has entered into interest rate
hedging transactions related to the anticipated issuance of senior notes
totaling approximately $125&nbsp;million. The notes are expected to be issued in
2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost debt and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital
if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">40
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF COMPREHENSIVE INCOME (UNAUDITED)


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="64%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the
second quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $155.7&nbsp;million and $299.6&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $158.5&nbsp;million and $291.8&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods in 2003. Earnings in the second quarter decreased by
$2.8&nbsp;million, or 1.8%, primarily due to higher non-fuel operating expenses
partially offset by higher retail base revenues when compared to the same
period in 2003. Earnings for year-to-date 2004 increased $7.8&nbsp;million, or
2.7%, primarily due to higher retail base revenues partially offset by higher
non-fuel operating expenses.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">N/M Not meaningful</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding fuel revenues, which generally do not affect net
income, retail sales revenue increased by $70.9&nbsp;million, or 9.7%, in the second
quarter 2004 compared to the corresponding period in 2003. In the second
quarter 2004, kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential, commercial and
industrial customers increased by 13.2%, 6.2% and 3.4%, respectively, when
compared to the same period in 2003. Year-to-date 2004 base retail sales
revenue increased by $102.8&nbsp;million, or 7.3%, compared to the corresponding
period in 2003. Year-to-date kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential,
commercial and industrial customers increased by 9.1%, 5.1% and 2.8%,
respectively, when compared to the same period in 2003. These increases in the
retail sectors during the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 are mainly due
to customer growth of 2%, more favorable weather, and an improving economy when
compared to the same periods in 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">46
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>.
During the second quarter and year-to-date 2004, fuel
expense was higher due to increases of 14.0% and 14.1%, respectively, in the
average cost of fuel and increases of 1.7% and 1.8%, respectively, in
generation due to increased retail sales. These expenses do not have a
significant impact on earnings since fuel expenses are generally offset by fuel
revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. See &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148;
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased
power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date
2004 increases in purchased power from non-affiliates are primarily due to
fluctuations in off-system energy purchases used to meet off-system sales
commitments. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings since
energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s
fuel cost recovery clause.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Purchased power from
affiliates increased in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 when compared
to the corresponding periods in 2003 due to a PPA between Georgia Power and
Southern Power that began in June&nbsp;2003. The capacity component of these
transactions increased $15.6&nbsp;million and $25.8&nbsp;million in the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004, respectively, over the same periods in 2003. The energy
component of power purchased from affiliated companies within the Southern
Company system will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company and will have no significant impact on
earnings since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through
Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>Other operations expense in the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 was higher when compared to the same periods in 2003 due
to increased administrative and general expenses of $8.0&nbsp;million and $13.8
million, respectively, related to increased employee benefit expenses and $3.2
million in workers compensation expenses for year-to-date 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense</I>. Maintenance expense was higher in the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 when compared to the same periods in 2003 due to the
timing of scheduled generating plant maintenance of $8.7&nbsp;million and $4.2
million, respectively, and scheduled transmission and distribution maintenance
of $10.2&nbsp;million and $13.2&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>In the second quarter and year-to-date
2004, depreciation and amortization expense was lower compared to the
corresponding periods in 2003. These decreases were caused primarily by lower
regulatory charges needed to levelize purchased power capacity costs under the
terms of the retail rate order effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. These decreases were
offset by increases in affiliated purchased power costs discussed above. See
Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Depreciation and
Amortization&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>. The second quarter
and year-to-date 2004 increases result primarily from the acquisition of the
McIntosh combined cycle units 10 and 11 construction project from Southern
Power. See &#147;FERC Matters&#148; herein and Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest income</I>. The second quarter and year-to-date 2004 decreases result
from $14.5&nbsp;million of interest on a favorable tax settlement received in the
second quarter of 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">47
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income (expense), net. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date
2004 decreases in other income (expense), net reflect decreased rental income of $4.0
million and $2.5&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as the impact of the ESOP
contribution in June&nbsp;2004 of $3.4&nbsp;million when compared to the same periods in
2003. The year-to-date 2004 decrease in other income (expense), net also
reflects a $5.0&nbsp;million decrease related to the 2003 favorable resolution of a
loss contingency.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in the service area. For
additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN
System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>New Source Review Actions and
Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information, including information on certain environmental
litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS -
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Plant Wansley
Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air
Act were increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per
violation. To the extent alleged violations under either the New Source Review
litigation or Plant Wansley environmental litigation are deemed to be
continuing, this increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations
found to continue after that date.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The case against Georgia Power had
been effectively stayed pending final resolution of the TVA case. With the
denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision became
final. At this time, no party to the case against Georgia Power has sought to
reopen the case, which remains administratively closed in the District Court
for the Northern District of Georgia.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;10, 2004, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia granted Georgia Power&#146;s motion in the Plant Wansley environmental
litigation for partial summary judgment regarding emissions offsets. The case
has been removed from the court&#146;s trial calendar due to pending motions for
summary judgment, and a new trial date has not been scheduled. An adverse
outcome in either of these cases could require substantial capital expenditures
that cannot be determined at this time and could possibly require payment of
substantial
penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash flows and
possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated
rates.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">48
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Global Warming
Litigation</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A nearly
identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same court.
The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits;
however, it intends to vigorously defend against these claims. While the
outcome cannot be determined at this time, an adverse judgment could result in
substantial capital expenditures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Other Environmental
Matters</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone nonattainment
designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new eight-hour
standard. Areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area that have been designated
as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard include Macon (Georgia)
and a 20-county area within metropolitan Atlanta. Under the implementation
provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour ozone standard
will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. Areas classified as &#147;severe&#148; nonattainment
areas under the one-hour standard will not be required to impose emissions fees
as a result of nonattainment. Georgia Power, therefore, will no longer be
subject to imposition of emissions fees if the Atlanta area does not come into
attainment with the one-hour standard. The impact of the eight-hour
designations and the new standards will depend on the development and
implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, the EPA issued its recommendations for areas to be
designated &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the fine particle national ambient air quality
standard. Areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area that were included in the
EPA&#146;s proposed fine particulate matter designations include 24 counties in the
metro-Atlanta area; counties surrounding Macon, Athens and Columbus, Georgia;
and counties in Georgia near Chattanooga, Tennessee.
Georgia Power owns several plants located within the counties proposed for the
nonattainment designations. The EPA plans to make final nonattainment
designations for fine particulate matter by the end of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to Georgia. These rules specify that the State of
Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by April&nbsp;2005, and
affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by May&nbsp;1, 2007.
The impact of these regulations
will depend on the development and approval of Georgia&#146;s state implementation
plan and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">49
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the
development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the
states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate
Authority</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Georgia
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under
&#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued
an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power. This new interim approach includes a
pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share analysis, the results of
which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding generation market power. The
FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for rebutting these presumptions and
addresses mitigation measures for those entities that are found to have market
power. In the absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes
several cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by default. The FERC
also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt
a final methodology for assessing generation market power. Southern Company,
the retail operating companies, including Georgia Power, and Southern Power
believe that it may be difficult for a traditional utility company, or an
affiliate thereof, with a significant load service obligation and generation to
satisfy that obligation, and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved
RTO, to pass all aspects of the market power screens as currently designed.
However, each of the companies believes that it has an appropriate basis to
rebut the generation market power presumption.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Plant McIntosh
Construction Project</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATION &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs
between Southern Power and Savannah Electric and Georgia Power for Plant
McIntosh capacity. In April&nbsp;2003, Southern Power applied for
FERC approval of these PPAs. In July&nbsp;2003, the FERC accepted the PPAs to
become effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, subject to refund and ordered that hearings be
held. To ensure the timely completion of


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">50
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">construction on McIntosh units 10 and 11 and their availability in the summer
of 2005 as supply side resources for the retail customers in the State of
Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric and Georgia Power requested the
Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the McIntosh construction project.
Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place the units in rate base at
a cost approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the unit operation and
maintenance costs as retail service expenses as may be approved by the Georgia
PSC. The Georgia PSC issued such an order on May&nbsp;18, 2004 and the transfer
occurred on May&nbsp;24, 2004. On May&nbsp;20, 2004, Southern Power
filed a request to withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the ongoing
FERC proceedings. On August&nbsp;4, 2004, the FERC issued a notice
that it allowed the request to withdraw the PPAs to be accepted and
to become effective by operation of law on July&nbsp;20, 2004.
However, the FERC made no determination on what additional steps may
need to be taken with respect to testimony provided in the proceedings. The
ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The May&nbsp;18, 2004 Georgia PSC order also directed Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric to file an application within 10&nbsp;days of completing such
purchase to amend the resource certificate granted by the Georgia PSC in 2002
to describe the capacity resource as being the McIntosh units 10 and 11 (as
opposed to the McIntosh PPAs), the approximate construction schedule (which is
not expected to change) and the proposed rate base treatment. The application
was filed on June&nbsp;3, 2004 and the Georgia PSC will have 180&nbsp;days to respond.
The Georgia PSC is expected to review the application in accordance with its
affiliate transaction guidelines, which require a lower of cost or market
approach unless otherwise determined by the Georgia PSC. Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric have submitted information showing that the book cost of the
McIntosh construction project is lower than its market value. However, full
recovery of the project costs depends on the outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s
review. In the event the Georgia PSC does not allow full recovery of the
project costs, then part of such costs may have to be written off in accordance
with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;90, &#147;Accounting for Abandonments and Disallowed Plant
Costs.&#148; At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the investment in the McIntosh construction project
totaled approximately $353.2&nbsp;million for Georgia Power. The ultimate outcome of
the Georgia PSC&#146;s review cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Rate Case</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;1, 2004, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC for an
approximate 7&nbsp;percent increase in retail revenues, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005.
The requested increase is based on a future test year ending July&nbsp;31, 2005 and
a proposed retail return on common equity of 12.5&nbsp;percent. Georgia Power is
currently operating under a three-year retail rate order that expires December
31, 2004. Under the terms of the existing order, earnings are evaluated
annually against a retail return on common equity range of 10&nbsp;percent to 12.95
percent. Two-thirds of any earnings above the 12.95&nbsp;percent return are applied
to rate refunds, with the remaining one-third retained by Georgia Power. The
order required Georgia Power to file a general rate case by July&nbsp;1, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in retail revenues is being requested to cover the higher
costs of purchased power; operating and maintenance expenses; environmental
compliance; and continued investment in new generation, transmission and
distribution facilities to support growth and ensure reliability. Georgia Power
expects the Georgia PSC to issue a final order in this matter during December
2004. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150;&nbsp;&#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
additional information.

</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Fuel Cost
Recovery</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In August&nbsp;2003, the Georgia PSC issued an order allowing Georgia Power to
increase customer fuel rates to collect existing under recovered fuel costs
over the period October&nbsp;1, 2003 through March&nbsp;31, 2005. Georgia Power has
experienced higher than expected fuel costs since the order was issued. Those
higher fuel costs have increased the under recovered fuel costs included in the
Condensed Balance Sheets herein. Georgia Power will continue to monitor the
under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these higher fuel costs. See Note
3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATION &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for information on nuclear security measures. Implementation plans for the
measures ordered by the NRC to be in effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been
finalized based on current interpretations of the requirements. Georgia Power,
based on its ownership interest, currently estimates its expenditures related
to these security measures will total $9.3&nbsp;million, of which 1.3&nbsp;million will
be capitalized. These estimates are subject to change in the event additional
NRC guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted at this
time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any,
arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
complete discussion of Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and
estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Georgia Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on
Georgia Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Georgia
Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Georgia Power does not meet the definition of primary
beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the
adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Georgia Power has elected to apply this treatment prospectively.
Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the subsidy effected
in the Medicare Act, Georgia Power does not anticipate a material impact on its
financial statements from the adoption of FSP No.&nbsp;106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Georgia Power&#146;s
financial condition during the first six months of 2004 included the addition
of approximately $672.4&nbsp;million to utility plant. The funds for these
additions and other capital requirements were derived primarily from operating
activities, short-term borrowings and equity funds from Southern Company. See
Georgia Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K for a description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for
its construction program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust
funding requirements. Approximately $302&nbsp;million will be required by June&nbsp;30,
2005 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt. The purchase of the
McIntosh construction project is expected to temporarily increase short-term
borrowings under the commercial paper program. The temporary increase will be
replaced with additional long-term debt. The projected construction program
will increase by $437.8&nbsp;million and $27.4&nbsp;million in 2004 and 2005,
respectively, for the Plant McIntosh combined cycle construction project and
the projected purchased power commitments will decrease by $133.2&nbsp;million in
2005-2006, $147.5&nbsp;million in 2007-2008 and $885.2&nbsp;million beyond 2008 as a
result of the purchase of the construction project.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, including funds from
operations and new security issuances. The amount, type and timing of
additional security issuances &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other
factors. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">53
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets because of the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which
can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet
short-term cash needs and contingencies, Georgia Power had at June&nbsp;30, 2004
approximately $20.3&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $773&nbsp;million of
unused credit arrangements with banks. Of these facilities, $423&nbsp;million expire
in 2005 and contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at
expiration; with the remaining $350&nbsp;million expiring in 2007. The credit
arrangements provide liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s obligations with
respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Georgia
Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration.
Georgia Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company
subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible
commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Georgia Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, Georgia Power had $372
million of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for
working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs
and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">
Georgia Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are contracts that could require collateral &#151; but not
accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases and agreements covering
interest rate swaps. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the maximum potential collateral
requirements were approximately $226&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be
provided for by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit or cash.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest
rate changes have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003
reporting period. In addition, Georgia Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Georgia Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Georgia Power has also
implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia
PSC. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at June&nbsp;30, 2004 was as
follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY  &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Georgia Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $100&nbsp;million of
Series&nbsp;S 4.00% Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2011 and $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;T
5.75% Senior Public Income Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these
sales were used in March&nbsp;2004 to redeem all of its outstanding Series&nbsp;H 6.70%
Senior Insured Quarterly Notes due March&nbsp;1, 2011 and Series&nbsp;D 6 5/8% Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;31, 2039. In February&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $150&nbsp;million
of Series&nbsp;U Floating Rate Senior Notes due February&nbsp;17, 2009. The proceeds of
this sale were used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further in January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power Capital Trust VII, a statutory
trust, sold $200&nbsp;million of its 5 7/8% Trust Preferred Securities, which are
guaranteed by Georgia Power. The net proceeds from this issuance were used to
redeem the 6.85% Trust Preferred Securities of Georgia Power Capital Trust IV.
In connection with this transaction, Georgia Power issued $206&nbsp;million of its
junior subordinated debentures to Georgia Power Capital Trust VII.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">55
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as they relate to Gulf Power are an integral part of these condensed financial statements.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as they relate to Gulf Power are an integral part of these condensed financial statements.

</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the second
quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $19.0&nbsp;million and $35.8&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $18.8&nbsp;million and $32.8&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods in 2003. Earnings in the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004 increased by $0.2&nbsp;million, or 1.2%, and $3.1&nbsp;million, or
9.4%, respectively, as a result of higher operating revenues that were only
partially offset with higher operating expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding the recovery of fuel expense and certain other
expenses that do not affect net income, retail sales increased by $0.8&nbsp;million,
or 0.8%, for the second quarter 2004 and by $4.9&nbsp;million, or 2.5%, year-to-date
2004 when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003. For both of the
reporting periods, retail sales revenues were higher than the corresponding
periods in 2003 primarily due to an increase in the number of customers and
more favorable weather. During the second quarter 2004, retail energy sales to
residential and industrial customers decreased by 0.3% and 5.2%, respectively,
while energy sales to commercial customers increased by 2.9% as compared to the
same period in 2003. For year-to-date 2004 as compared to 2003, retail energy
sales to residential and commercial customers increased by 2.3% and 3.2%,
respectively, while energy sales to industrial customers decreased by 1.5%. The
decreases in industrial sales for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 are
primarily the result of permanent load reductions and customer operational
issues, which vary from period to period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates and purchases of energy from affiliates
will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating
resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by
energy revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. The
increases in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 sales for resale to
affiliates are due to increased sales of available


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">61
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">generation to affiliate companies at a higher unit cost resulting from higher
fuel prices. The increase in purchased power from affiliates in the second
quarter 2004 is primarily due to higher priced peak hour energy purchases that
resulted from increased fuel prices. The decrease in purchased power from
affiliates for year-to-date 2004 is primarily due to an increase in Gulf Power
generation to meet its load requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>During the second quarter and year-to-date 2004, fuel
expense increased from the corresponding periods in 2003 primarily due to a
significant increase in the use of gas generation to meet additional demand for
energy. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through
Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do not have a
material impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates. </I>The increases for the second quarter
and year-to-date 2004, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003, are
primarily attributed to Gulf Power&#146;s increased purchase of off-system power
from merchant generation resources in order to reduce total system energy
production costs. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy
revenues, these expenses do not have a significant impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The increase in other operations expense during
the second quarter 2004 is primarily due to a $2.0&nbsp;million increase in employee
benefit expenses and a $1.2&nbsp;million increase in accrued expenses for uninsured
litigation and workers compensation claims. The increase in other operations
expense for year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding period in 2003
is primarily due to a $3.4&nbsp;million increase in employee benefit expenses, a
$1.3&nbsp;million increase in expenses related to marketing conservation programs
and a $1.2&nbsp;million increase in accrued expenses for uninsured litigation and
workers compensation claims.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The increases in taxes other than income
taxes for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily due to
increased franchise fees and gross receipts taxes resulting from increased
revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The increases in other income (expense), net
for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 when compared to the same periods
in 2003 are primarily due to higher AFUDC related to the environmental controls project at Plant
Crist.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors, including Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent
environmental standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of
factors, which include weather, competition, new energy contracts with
neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in
the service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see
BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148;
of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">62
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
