<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs are not fully recovered through
Gulf Power&#146;s Environmental Cost Recovery Clause. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151;
Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of Gulf Power and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were
increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the
extent alleged violations under the New Source Review litigation are deemed to
be continuing, this increased civil penalty amount could apply to such
violations found to continue after that date.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against TVA. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition
for review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome in
the New Source Review litigation described in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K could
require substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require substantial
penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash flows, and
possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated
rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of
Southern Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York
City filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits;
however, it intends to vigorously defend against these claims. While the
outcome cannot be determined at this time, an adverse judgment could result in
substantial capital expenditures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the states, and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate Authority</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of
Gulf Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004,
the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring generation


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">63
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">market power.
This new interim approach includes a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale
market share analysis, the results of which provide a rebuttable presumption
regarding generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures
for rebutting these presumptions and addresses mitigation measures for those
entities that are found to have market power. In the absence of specific
mitigation measures, the order includes several cost-based mitigation measures
that would apply by default. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking
proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for
assessing generation market power. Southern Company, the retail operating
companies, including Gulf Power, and Southern Power believe that it may be
difficult for a traditional utility company, or an affiliate thereof, with a
significant load service obligation and generation to satisfy that obligation,
and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved RTO, to pass all aspects of
the market power screens as currently designed. However, each of the companies
believes that it has an appropriate basis to rebut the generation market power
presumption.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Transmission</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and notice of
proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service and standard
electricity market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><I>Other Matters</I></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the
ordinary course of business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the
environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types,
including property damage, personal injury and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged
exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at this time;
however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising
from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Gulf
Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">64
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;
ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion
of Gulf Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Gulf Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Gulf
Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Gulf Power
deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Gulf Power does not meet the definition of primary beneficiary
established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the adoption
of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Gulf Power has elected to apply this treatment prospectively.
Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the subsidy effected
in the Medicare Act, Gulf Power does not anticipate a material impact on its
financial statements from the adoption of FSP No. 106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition during the first six months
of 2004 included the addition of approximately $70.2&nbsp;million to utility plant.
The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were derived
primarily from operating activities. See Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of
Cash Flows herein for further details.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">65
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Reference is made to MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for a description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction
program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Gulf Power plans to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past. These sources include cash flows from
operating activities and issuances of unsecured debt, trust preferred
securities, preferred stock and pollution control bonds issued for Gulf Power&#146;s
benefit by public authorities. The amount, type and timing of any future
financings, if needed, will depend upon market conditions and regulatory
approval. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Gulf Power has various
internal and external sources of liquidity. In addition, Gulf Power has
substantial cash flow from operating activities. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power
had approximately $12.8&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $56.3&nbsp;million
of unused committed lines of credit with banks. Of these facilities, $10
million expire in 2004 and the remaining $46.3&nbsp;million expire in 2005. Gulf
Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration.
The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s obligations
with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper.
Gulf Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company
subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible
commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Gulf Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. At June&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power had $5.0&nbsp;million
of commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for working
capital can be adequately met by utilizing lines of credit without maintaining
large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not
changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period. In
addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances
that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">66
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Gulf Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Gulf Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase of coal
supplies, the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale
electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas
purchases. Gulf Power has received approval from the Florida PSC to recover
prudently incurred costs related to its fuel hedging program through the fuel
cost recovery mechanism. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at June
30, 2004 was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and
Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Financial
Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for further information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In April&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $35&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;J 5.875% Senior Notes
due April&nbsp;1, 2044. The proceeds from this issue were used for general corporate
purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Gulf Power&#146;s
capital requirements and contractual obligations, Gulf Power plans to continue,
when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost debt and replace
these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">67
</DIV>

    <TD width="64%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the
second quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $21. 9&nbsp;million and $39.2&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $53.1&nbsp;million and $74.5&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods of 2003. Earnings in the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004 decreased by $31.2&nbsp;million or 58.8%, and $35.3&nbsp;million, or
47.4%, respectively, primarily as a result of the 2003 gain of $38&nbsp;million
after tax related to the termination of a PPA with
Dynegy. This decrease was partially offset by the net impact of an $11&nbsp;million
decrease in other operations expense related to costs incurred in the second
quarter of 2003 to restructure the lease agreement for the combined cycle
generating units at Plant Daniel, and an increase of $11.8&nbsp;million in pretax
earnings in the second quarter of 2004 resulting from the impact of the
Mississippi PSC&#146;s order approving the inclusion of the Plant Daniel capacity in
jurisdictional cost of service. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Contract Termination&#148; and &#147;Retail Regulatory Filing&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Retail sales
revenue increased $17.8&nbsp;million, or 13.3%, in
the second quarter 2004 and $32.4&nbsp;million or 13.1% year-to-date 2004 when
compared to the same periods in 2003. The increases in retail sales revenues
are primarily as a result of an increase of $18.6&nbsp;million in the second quarter
2004 and $32.2&nbsp;million year-to-date 2004 in fuel revenues, which generally do
not have an effect on income. Retail sales revenues, excluding fuel revenues,
for the second quarter 2004 to residential, commercial and industrial customers
decreased 2.4%, 1.3% and 0.4%, respectively, primarily as a result of mild
weather when compared to the same
period in 2003. Retail sales revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for
year-to-date 2004 from residential, commercial and industrial customers
remained mostly constant as compared to the same period in 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">73
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The increase in sales for resale to
non-affiliates in the second quarter 2004 as compared to the same period in
2003 is primarily due to the increased fuel revenue from wholesale territorial
customers and increased energy sales to non-territorial customers.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates, as well as purchases of energy from
affiliates, will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since the energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by
energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses. The increase in sales for resale to affiliates is primarily
a result of Mississippi Power&#146;s more economical generating costs when compared
to others. The increase in purchased power from affiliates is primarily due to
the increase in the cost of fuel.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the second quarter and year-to-date 2004, fuel expense
increased when compared to the same periods in 2003 as a result of 4.2% and
10.1% increases in generation, respectively, and a 42.5% and 50.6% increase in
cost of oil and gas, respectively. Since energy expenses are generally offset
by energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses, these expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates</I>. The second quarter and year-to-date
2004 increases in purchased power from non-affiliates when compared to the same
periods in 2003 are a result of increased purchased power demand as a result of
planned outages at generating units for maintenance purposes in 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in other operation expense when compared to the same periods in 2003
are a result of approximately $11&nbsp;million incurred during the second quarter
2003 to restructure the lease agreement for the combined cycle generating units
at Plant Daniel. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;Operating Leases &#150; Plant Daniel Combined Cycle Generating Units&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in depreciation and amortization expense when compared to the same
periods in 2003 are primarily the result of the amortization of a regulatory
liability as approved by the Mississippi PSC. The Mississippi PSC issued an
interim accounting order in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi Power to
expense and record in 2003 a regulatory liability in the amount of
approximately $60&nbsp;million. Based on the final Mississippi PSC order issued May
25, 2004 that approved this treatment, Mississippi Power recorded during the
second quarter a credit to expense in the amount of $8.3&nbsp;million to amortize
the regulatory liability retroactive to January&nbsp;1, 2004. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Filing&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements and
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters &#150; Retail Rate
Filing&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense. </I>The decreases in interest expense for the second
quarter and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in 2003 are a
result of lower interest rates. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; of Mississippi Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing
Activities&#148; herein for further information on efforts to reduce interest rates.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">74
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date decreases in income
taxes of $18.1&nbsp;million, or 54.6%, and $20.7&nbsp;million, or 44.3%, respectively,
are a result of the $47.3&nbsp;million and $53.9&nbsp;million, respectively, reduction in
earnings before income taxes when compared to the same periods in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock. </I>The second quarter and year-to-date 2004
increases in dividends on preferred stock are the result of a $2.0&nbsp;million loss
on the redemption of preferred stock recognized in the second quarter of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in the service area. For
additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN
System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of Mississippi
Power in the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s 2004 ECO Plan filing was approved, as filed, by the
Mississippi PSC on March&nbsp;15, 2004, and resulted in a slight decrease in rates
effective April&nbsp;2004. Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other
environmental regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue
to be recovered. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF
OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;New Source
Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil
penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a maximum of
$32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent alleged violations under the New
Source Review litigation are deemed to be continuing, this increased civil
penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue after that
date.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review the
Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review action against the TVA. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for
review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome in the
New Source Review litigation described in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K could require
substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require substantial
penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash flows, and
possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated
rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of
Southern Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York
City filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance.
Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the alternative,
under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups also seek relief
under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs seek a judicial
order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable for creating,
contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance, global warming
and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">75
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">defendants to abate its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions
of carbon dioxide and then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage
each year for at least a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that
damages be awarded in connection with their claims. Southern Company believes
these claims are without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory
or regulatory basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits; however, it intends to
vigorously defend against these claims. While the outcome cannot be determined
at this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the states, and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate
Authority</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC
issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis
for measuring generation market power. The FERC also initiated a new
rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology
for assessing generation market power. Southern Company, the retail operating
companies, including Mississippi Power, and Southern Power believe that it may
be difficult for a traditional utility company, or an affiliate thereof, with a
significant load service obligation and generation to satisfy that obligation,
and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved RTO, to pass all aspects of
the market power screens as currently designed. However, each of the companies
believes that it has an appropriate basis to rebut the generation market power
presumption.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time. See Note (B)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; herein for additional
information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;  RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order
related to RTOs and the notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access
transmission service and standard electricity market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Rate Filing</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On December&nbsp;5, 2003, Mississippi Power filed a request with the Mississippi PSC
to reclassify 266 megawatts


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">76
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">of Plant Daniel Units 3 and 4 generating capacity not currently included in
jurisdictional cost of service. As part of Mississippi Power&#146;s proposal to
include the additional Plant Daniel capacity in retail rates, the Mississippi
PSC issued an interim accounting order in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi
Power to expense and record in 2003 a regulatory liability in the amount of
approximately $60&nbsp;million while the Mississippi PSC fully considered the entire
request. On May&nbsp;25, 2004, the Mississippi PSC issued an order related to this
matter. The Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s request to reclassify
the 266 megawatts of Plant Daniel unit 3 and 4 capacity to jurisdictional cost
of service effective January&nbsp;1, 2004, and authorized Mississippi Power to
include the related costs and revenue credits in jurisdictional rate base, cost
of service and revenue requirement calculations for purposes of retail rate
recovery. As directed by the Mississippi PSC, Mississippi Power will amortize
the regulatory liability established pursuant to the Mississippi PSC&#146;s interim
order in December&nbsp;2003 as an increase to earnings as follows: $16.5&nbsp;million in
2004, $25.1&nbsp;million in 2005, $13.0&nbsp;million in 2006 and $5.7&nbsp;million in 2007.
The impact of the order on earnings for the period January&nbsp;1, 2004 through June
30, 2004 is an increase of $7.3&nbsp;million after tax and is reflected in the
second quarter 2004 financial statements of Mississippi Power. See Note 3 to
the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Filing&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Mississippi PSC also approved Mississippi Power&#146;s
requested changes to its PEP including the use of a forward-looking test year,
with appropriate oversight; annual, rather than semi-annual, filings; and
certain changes to the performance indicator mechanisms. Rate changes will be
limited to 4% of retail revenues annually under the revised PEP. The
Mississippi PSC will review all aspects of PEP in 2007.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the
ordinary course of business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Mississippi Power cannot be
predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from any such current proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Mississippi Power&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Mississippi Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no
impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the
adoption, Mississippi Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts
established to issue preferred securities since Mississippi Power does not meet
the definition of primary beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.
46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information related to the adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Mississippi Power has elected to apply this treatment
prospectively. Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the
subsidy effected in the Medicare Act, Mississippi Power does not anticipate a
material impact on its financial statements from the adoption of FSP No.&nbsp;106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition during the first six
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $32&nbsp;million to utility
plant, a reduction in current liabilities of $93&nbsp;million, an increase of $40
million in long-term debt and a decrease of $65&nbsp;million in cash. See
Mississippi Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows and &#147;Financing
Activities&#148; herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item
7 in the Form 10-K for a description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital
requirements for its construction program, lease obligations, purchase
commitments and trust funding requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Mississippi Power
plans to obtain the funds required for
construction and other purposes from sources similar to those used in the past.
The amount, type and timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon
maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval,
prevailing market conditions and other factors. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing
Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for additional information.

</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at
June&nbsp;30, 2004, approximately $3.9&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $100
million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks. Of these
facilities, $35&nbsp;million expire in 2004 and the remaining $65&nbsp;million expire in
2005. Approximately $37.5&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date.
Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi
Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs
through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of
Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At June&nbsp;30, 2004,
Mississippi Power had $44.8&nbsp;million in outstanding notes payable. Management
believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing
lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY
&#151;
&#147;Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a
combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit agreements that would require
material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit
rating downgrade.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes
have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting
period. In addition, Mississippi Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure
to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Mississippi Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase
and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Mississippi
Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of
the Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with
wholesale customers. The fair values of derivative, fuel and energy contracts
at June&nbsp;30, 2004 were as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued $40&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;F Floating Rate
Senior Notes due March&nbsp;9, 2009. The proceeds from this sale, along with other
monies of Mississippi Power, were used to repay at maturity $80&nbsp;million
aggregate principal amount of Mississippi Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;D Floating Rate Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;12, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued 1,200,000 Depositary Shares ($30
million aggregate stated capital) each representing one-fourth of a share of
5.25% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock, cumulative, par value $100 per share. The
proceeds from this sale were primarily used to redeem various issues of higher
cost preferred stock and the remainder was used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program
to retire higher-cost debt and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">80
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">SECOND QUARTER 2004 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s net income for the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 was
$7.3&nbsp;million and $10.5&nbsp;million, respectively, compared to $6.3&nbsp;million and $9.8
million, respectively, for the corresponding periods of 2003. Earnings
increased by $1.1&nbsp;million, or 16.7%, in the second quarter 2004 primarily due
to higher operating revenues and other income, net, partially offset by higher
operating expenses. Year-to-date 2004 earnings were up by $0.7&nbsp;million, or
7.1%, as a result of higher operating revenues, also partially offset by higher
operating expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales</I>. Excluding fuel revenues, which do not affect net income,
retail sales revenue increased by $4.5&nbsp;million, or 10.2%, in the second quarter
2004 and increased by $6.5&nbsp;million, or 7.9%, year-to-date 2004 when compared to
the corresponding periods in 2003. The second quarter 2004 increase in retail
sales revenue is mainly attributed to an 11.7% increase in retail kilowatt-hour
energy sales. Energy sales to residential and commercial customers were higher
by 12.0% and 12.5%, respectively, mainly due to more favorable weather
conditions and growth in the number of customers when compared to the same
period in 2003. Energy sales to industrial customers increased by 9.3% in the
second quarter 2004 compared to the second quarter 2003 primarily due to
increased usage by several industrial customers as a result of the improving
economy. The year-to-date 2004 increase in retail revenues is primarily a
result of more favorable weather conditions and growth in the number of
customers. Year-to-date 2004, energy sales to residential and commercial
customers were higher by 14.1% and 7.4%, respectively. Energy sales to
industrial customers year-to-date 2004 were down 4.4% when compared to the
prior year mainly due to the installation of a cogeneration facility by one
customer in late 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates. </I>Revenues from sales for resale to
affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company.
Sales for resale to affiliates increased in the second quarter and year-to-date
2004 primarily due to an increase in demand. These transactions do not have a
significant impact on net income.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">86
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense increased in the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004 primarily as a result of increased generation to meet demand
for energy and increases in the price of fuel. Generation increased 4.8% for
second quarter and 3.2% for year-to-date 2004 when compared to the prior year.
Fuel costs increased 7.1% for second quarter 2004. Since fuel expenses are
generally offset by fuel revenues through Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost
recovery clause, these expenses do not have a significant impact on net income.
See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Georgia PSC
Matters &#151; Fuel Cost
Recovery Rate Filings&#148; and Note (L)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>In the second quarter and year-to-date
2004, the increases in purchased power from non-affiliates are primarily due to
higher demand and the opportunity to purchase this energy at a cost lower than
self-generation or available from affiliates. These transactions do not have a
significant impact on earnings, as energy costs are generally recovered through
Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Purchased power from affiliates increased
in the second quarter and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in
the prior year primarily due to the availability of system generation at prices
below self generation to meet increased sales demand and also as the result of
an accounting order approved by the Georgia PSC in December&nbsp;2002 which allows
Savannah Electric to write-down a portion of the approximately $3.8&nbsp;million
annual deferral in Plant Wansley purchased power costs.
See Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;Retail
Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. The
net impact of these transactions compared to the prior year was a $0.6&nbsp;million
increase to expense for the second quarter and a $0.9&nbsp;million increase
year-to-date. Purchased power from affiliates also includes energy purchases
which will vary depending on demand and cost of generation resources at each
company and higher energy costs. These energy costs are recovered through the
fuel cost recovery clause and have no significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense</I>. The increases for the second quarter and
year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in the prior year in other
operations expense are attributed to an increase in administrative and general
expenses primarily relating to accounting and auditing services, legal and
employee benefit expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increases in the second quarter and year-to-date
2004 as compared to the same periods in the prior year are mainly due to an
unscheduled coal mill repair at Plant Kraft.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The second quarter and
year-to-date 2004 increases in this expense as compared to the same period in
the prior year are mainly due to an increase in long term debt outstanding.
These increases were more than offset by decreases in distributions on
mandatorily redeemable preferred securities. These preferred securities were
redeemed in January&nbsp;2004 with proceeds from the issuance of senior notes in
late 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Savannah Electric&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation
practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of
demand and the rate of economic growth in the service area. For additional
information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">87
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to
the financial statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the
Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per
violation. To the extent alleged violations under either the New Source Review
litigation or Plant Wansley environmental litigation are deemed to be
continuing, this increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations
found to continue after that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court
denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146;
decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source Review enforcement action against the
TVA. The case against Savannah Electric has been effectively stayed pending
final resolution of the TVA case. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for
review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision became final. At this time, no party to
the case against Savannah Electric has sought to reopen that case, which
remains administratively closed in the District Court for the Northern District
of Georgia. An adverse outcome in this case could require substantial capital
expenditures that cannot be determined at this time and could possibly require
payment of substantial penalties. This could affect future results of
operations, cash flows, and possibly financial condition if such costs are not
recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of
Southern Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York
City filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company has not yet responded to the suits;
however, it intends to vigorously defend against these claims. While the
outcome cannot be determined at this time, an adverse judgment could result in
substantial capital expenditures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to the State of Georgia. These rules specify that
Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by April&nbsp;2005, and
affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by May&nbsp;1, 2007.
The impact of these regulations will depend on the development and approval of
Georgia&#146;s state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will
depend on the development and implementation of the final rules and
implementation by the states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">88
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate
Authority</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that
abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power. This new interim approach includes a pivotal supplier
analysis and a wholesale market share analysis, the results of which provide a
rebuttable presumption regarding generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order
also sets forth procedures for rebutting these presumptions and addresses
mitigation measures for those entities that are found to have market power. In
the absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes several
cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by default. The FERC also
initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a
final methodology for assessing generation market power. Southern Company, the
retail operating companies, including Savannah Electric, and Southern Power
believe that it may be difficult for a traditional utility company, or an
affiliate thereof, with a significant load service obligation and generation to
satisfy that obligation, and that is not a member of a large, FERC-approved
RTO, to pass all aspects of the market power screens as currently designed.
However, each of the companies believes that it has an appropriate basis to
rebut the generation market power presumption.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company will submit the required analyses by August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power and the retail operating companies may be required to
charge cost-based rates, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates.
The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item
7 of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Plant McIntosh
Construction Project</u>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Southern Power PPAs&#148; of Savannah Electric
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under
&#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs
between Southern Power and Savannah Electric and Georgia Power for Plant
McIntosh capacity. In April&nbsp;2003, Southern Power applied for
FERC approval of these PPAs. In July&nbsp;2003, the FERC accepted the PPAs to
become effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, subject to refund and ordered that hearings be
held. To ensure the timely completion of construction on McIntosh units 10 and
11 and their availability in the summer of 2005 as supply side resources for
the retail customers in the State of Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric
and Georgia Power requested the Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the
McIntosh construction project.
Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place the units in rate base at
a cost approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the unit operation and
maintenance costs as retail service expenses as may be approved by the Georgia
PSC. The Georgia PSC issued such an order on May&nbsp;18, 2004 and the transfer


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">89
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">occurred on May&nbsp;24,
2004. On May&nbsp;20, 2004, Southern Power filed a request to
withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the ongoing FERC proceedings. On
August&nbsp;4, 2004, the FERC issued a notice that it allowed the
request to withdraw the PPAs to be accepted and to become effective
by operation of law on July&nbsp;20, 2004. However, the FERC made no
determination on what additional steps may need to be taken with
respect to testimony provided in the proceedings. The ultimate outcome of this
matter cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The May&nbsp;18, 2004 Georgia PSC order also directed Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric to file an application within 10&nbsp;days of completing such
purchase to amend the resource certificate granted by the Georgia PSC in 2002
to describe the capacity resource as being the McIntosh units 10 and 11 (as
opposed to the McIntosh PPAs), the approximate construction schedule (which is
not expected to change) and the proposed rate base treatment. The application
was filed on June&nbsp;3, 2004 and the Georgia PSC will have 180&nbsp;days to respond.
The Georgia PSC is expected to review the application in accordance with its
affiliate transaction guidelines, which require a lower of cost or market
approach unless otherwise determined by the Georgia PSC. Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric have submitted information showing that the book cost of the
McIntosh construction project is lower than its market value. However, full
recovery of the project costs depends on the outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s
review. In the event the Georgia PSC does not allow full recovery of the
project costs, then part of such costs may have to be written off in accordance
with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;90, &#147;Accounting for Abandonments and Disallowed Plant
Costs.&#148; At June&nbsp;30, 2004, the investment in the McIntosh construction project
totaled approximately $69.7&nbsp;million for Savannah Electric. The ultimate outcome
of the Georgia PSC&#146;s review cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Fuel Cost Recovery Rate Filings</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;23, 2004, Savannah Electric submitted a request to the Georgia PSC for
an accounting order which, if approved by the Georgia PSC, would have allowed
for the cost of a coal transloader then under construction to be amortized over
twenty-four months through fuel expense and recovered through Savannah
Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. The transloader allows foreign coal to
be off-loaded from ships at Savannah Electric&#146;s Plant Kraft dock, and then
transferred by rail to Plant McIntosh. On June&nbsp;24, 2004, the Georgia PSC denied
Savannah Electric&#146;s request for this accounting order. Consequently,
accumulated project costs of $2.7&nbsp;million were recorded as construction work in
progress in June&nbsp;2004 and will be depreciated over the project&#146;s estimated
useful life of 35&nbsp;years once placed in service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric filed for a fuel cost recovery rate
increase with the Georgia PSC. The increase will allow for the recovery of fuel
costs based on an estimate of future costs, as well as the collection of the
existing under recovery of fuel expenses, over a two-year period. The amount
under recovered at June&nbsp;30, 2004 is approximately $8.9&nbsp;million and is included
in Savannah Electric&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets herein. The Georgia PSC is
expected to rule on this matter by late October&nbsp;2004. The outcome of the
filing cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Retail Rate Case</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric anticipates filing a base rate case in late 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the
ordinary course of business. In addition, Savannah Electric&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Savannah Electric&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item 7 of the Form
10-K for a complete discussion of Savannah Electric&#146;s critical accounting
policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent
Obligations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Savannah Electric prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Savannah
Electric under &#147;Mandatorily Redeemable Preferred Securities&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K regarding Savannah Electric&#146;s redemption of all outstanding preferred
securities in January&nbsp;2004 and the dissolution of the issuing trust.
Therefore, the adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Savannah
Electric&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the FASB approved Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements related to the Medicare Prescription Drug,
Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &#147;Medicare Act&#148;).&#148; FSP No.
106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of the Medicare Act in the
accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation and future cost of service for
post-retirement medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment
of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third
quarter 2004. Savannah Electric has elected to apply this treatment
prospectively. Pending the finalization of federal regulations governing the
subsidy effected in the Medicare Act, Savannah Electric does not anticipate a
material impact on its financial statements from the adoption of FSP No.&nbsp;106-2.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Savannah Electric&#146;s financial condition during the first six
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $95.9&nbsp;million to utility
plant, which include the Plant McIntosh combined cycle construction project.
See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities, issuance of securities, capital
contributions from Southern Company and short-term debt. See Savannah
Electric&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.
